config.question: In addition to the white Irish, English, and Scandinavian immigrants, why were immigrants from Mexico also considered exempt from the otherwise racially biased National Origins Quota Act?

choices.content: Mexican laborers were admitted to fill the continuing need for unskilled workers on farms and in the service trades.
Previously negotiated border treaties between the United States and its southern neighbor opened the border and prohibited attempts to obstruct crossings.
As the demand for assembly-line workers in the nation’s factories grew, industry owners lobbied Congress for relaxed immigration laws related to Mexico.
The National Origins Quota Act excluded Asians only and did not limit immigration from other European or South American countries.

answer_3.response: The quota system enforced a racist bias that excluded Asians and limited the immigration of Italians, Greeks, and Poles to a few thousand a year while permitting a steady stream of Irish, English, and Scandinavian immigrants. Large corporations, no longer dependent on armies of unskilled immigrant workers, did not object to the 1924 law. Yet the victory for “nativists” was incomplete. A growing tide of Mexican laborers, exempt from the quota act, flowed across the Rio Grande to fill the continuing need for unskilled workers on farms and in the service trades.
